216. Conlin, Edith Laura (Mrs. William A.)
THAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN FARMERS EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Sask.)

Name Mrs. W. Conlin
Address GLADWORTH, SASK.
Birthplace ONTARIO

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1947
Where did you set up housekeeping? GLADWORTH, SASK.
Where had you been living before that? REMEREW, Ontario
For how many people did you prepare meals? 12
How far was it to your nearest store? 3 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Every day
What groceries did you usually buy in those earlier years?
flour, tea, coffee, sugar, salt, spices, vinegar, fruit.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Robin Hood

In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lb. bags
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? 2 cents
How much did you use Graham flour? 20 lbs.
Whole wheat flour? 10 lbs.
Was flour milled locally? No, how far away? 50 miles
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats?
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? Yes, how much? 10 lbs.
Parino? Yes
Other?

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No
How did you grind it?

Name: Mrs. W. S. Conlin
Address: Gladworth, Sask., Ontario

1. What year did you start homesteading in eastern Canada? (1907)

2. How many people did you have living there? (7)

3. How far was it to your nearest store? (5 miles)

4. How often could a visit be made to the store? (Weekly)

5. What groceries did you usually buy in those early days? (Flour, sugar, tea, coffee, butter, eggs)

6. What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? (Hard)

7. In what quantities did you buy? (100 lbs.)

8. How much did you pay per hundred pounds? ($2.50)

9. Was flour milled locally? (Yes)

10. What was the price for a twenty pound bag of flour? ($1.00)

11. Did you raise your own meat for preserves? (Yes)

12. How did you feel at first? (Excited)
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 100 lb.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? $7.00

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Kroger

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 10 lb.

At what price?

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? Cow

Butter? churned. Cream eggs? fresh

What was the price of butter? $2.00 of eggs? $1.50

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes how? Winter storage

Did you make butter? Yes cheese? No

What kind of cheese?

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Pork, Beef & Poultry

How did you get fresh meat? Butcher shop in winter

and in spring I bought it

How often did you get fresh meat? In winter

How did you preserve meat? Canned & Salted

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? No

If so what year was it organized?

Did you use game? Yes What kinds?

For how long?

What part did fish play in the family diet? About 3 meals a week

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh & also canned

Kinds? White fish - Tuna fish - Salmon

At what prices?

Butter? Cream? Cheese?

What kind of tea did you buy? Blue Ribbon at what price? $3.00.
What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Ground.
Price? $2.50. What other beverages were used?

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? $2.50.
Could you get potatoes at the store? Yes.
If not, where from?

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:
Potatoes 1907, Cabbage 1907, Carrots 1907, Onions 1907,
Turnips 1907, Beets 1907.

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 10 lbs.

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? By the box.
What weight? 5 lbs. How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? Loose.
What was the price of prunes? $1.00.

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, peaches, apricots, pears, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)?

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? Peaches.
Peas? Yes. Corn? Beans? Yes. Saskatoons? Other foods?

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1907.
What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1910.
What year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1910.
Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Yes.

To what extent? 100-90%.
Did you make your own vinegar? Yes.
6. NEW CROPS

What kind of crop did you buy? ... Beans, Peas, Potatoes, etc.

What kind of coffee did you buy? (name or brand) ... Ground Coffee

Price ... $2.50

What other dried fruit did you use in the summer? (apples, pears, peaches, plums, raisins, currants, etc.)?

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by freezing? ... No

Preserve? ... No

Other foods? ... No

That year did you first preserve fruit by canning? ... 1910

That year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? ... 1910

That year did you first preserve meat by canning? ... 1910

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? ... Yes

To what extent? ... 10% - 25%

Did you make your own vinegar? ... Yes

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

1907
Breakfast - oatmeal porridge, eggs, toast, fried potatoes, jam or syrup, tea or coffee.
Dinner - salt pork, potatoes, vegetables, dried apple pie or pudding, beverage.
Supper - salt pork, potatoes, fruit, cookies, hard cheese, cake, beverage.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada? 1907

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

Turkey, potatoes, vegetables, pickles, mince pie, plum pudding, beverage.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details. No.

   *Give a day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the date and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. Also give approximate names, etc., of other or minor.*

   *Breakfast - oatmeal porridge, eggs, toast*

   *Lunch - fried potatoes, cream or gravy, tea or coffee*

   *Locality unknown*
20. Mention any substantial differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

- More prepared foods now.
- Bread mostly bought.
- Uncooked cereals used.
- Electric for stove.
- Pots, aluminum, steel utensils.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homemade and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

- 1917 - Baker's Bread
- 1925 - Cereals
- 1945 - Cake and biscuit mixes

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Eastern Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of recommendation, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).
21. What did you begin to rely on particular foods and products from before or during the war?

- 1917 - Baker's Bread
- 1925 - Weetabix
- 1945 - Cake and tin tins
